entry.title: High Low There
entry.summary: I had to write again. Can't start 2026 like an absurd…
entry.content:
I had to write again.

Can't start 2026 like an absurd person would.

That was so 2025.

Listen, I got a question:

Do you have to get really low to get really high?

I mean to know what high truly means.

Do you have to be poor to appreciate being wealthy?

Do you have to have your heart broken to treasure and enjoy real love?

I mean, to value it as you should:

Priceless.Â 

If you were born rich, you tend to stay it, and take it for granted.

You wouldn't fully understand its literal value unless you lost it.

Same with love, I think, an always in love, never broken, heart. Seems like that kind of heart would break others' hearts.

You don't appreciate the unlimited power of love until it breaks you or someone close to you.

The more I wrestle with it, the more I am learning that our point of view, our perspective, might be one of the only truly unique things we have.

We all own a unique, one of one, perspective. A set of lenses through which we live.

And as similar as some things may be, you'll find stark differences the further you zoom in.

So the challenge, then, should you choose to accept it is:

Learn from your singular perspective and the infinite of others.

Why do you (and they) see the world the way you (and they [this is the last time I will do the "and they" thing so just put it after every "you" following]) do?

How do you define wealth? Is it good or evil? And why?

How do you define love? Is it good or evil? Do you still believe in it? And why?

How do you define yourself? Are you good or evil? Do you still believe in you? And why?

And, perhaps most importantly, how do you define God? Is God benevolent or malevolent? Did you ever, or do you still, believe? And why?

entry.title: MMXXVI
entry.summary: Two Ms. Two Xs. A V and an I. That spells…
entry.content:
Two Ms. Two Xs. A V and an I.

That spells Ememexexveeeeye.

Or something.

Rolls off the tongue, don't it?

Apparently, these are numerals but they look like capital letters if you ask me.

I am partial to LX, though.

60. And kinda, sorta, my name.

LX is the new XXIX (was going to say 30, but yeah), so I hear.

When in Rome...

Get ready, people.

Things will start out fast and hot.

I can feel it in my vibes.

May your Ememexexveeeeye be better than your Ememexexveee.

entry.title: Party Horn
entry.summary: Well, hey. Long time. What's it been, a year? Guffaw. I…
entry.content:
Well, hey.

Long time.

What's it been, a year?

Guffaw.

I so funny.

Guffaws again.

Give me a second here.

Ok.

Man, I'm good.

So witty.

So this is my way of starting the new year on this here daily journal thing.

If you're new here, I ramble. Rant. Reason. Revere.

Mostly, this is my mental playground.Â 

Where I get to flip around and jump and flow my brain and finger muscles.

I'd love for you to join me.

Actually, I couldn't care less if you did, it just seems like people say that.

Ooooooooh, honorable reader, will you join my journey, please?

[Farts slowly, loudly, still going...you wonder "How does he do that?" The author, staring at you the whole time, never breaks eye contact. It is almost melodic. And ends on a high note, which, strangely, delights you. You got a few seconds before the smell hits. I would leave.]

Â

entry.title: Ramble, Old Man, Ramble
entry.summary: Only been writing again for the last couple of months, but…
entry.content:
Only been writing again for the last couple of months, but it feels like a longer time.

I've been blessed (cursed?) with the ability to stop things I loved doing without missing it much.

I used to define myself by how much I could lift off my chest or over my head.

Always a spiritual sort, I prayed to heavy metal listening to heavy metal.

Found God there (and in a Muay Thai gym).

But I don't do it anymore.

Or at least for now I don't.

And I don't miss it (much).

You'd think I would, because it was a really big part of me, a big part of how I defined myself.

And that's how I kind of feel about writing.

I have written my entire life.

Have always loved the written word.

For a long time, I couldn't read or write anymore.

And that sucked. More than the not lifting thing. Which shocks me, writing that truth.

I started listening to stories and watching them.

And that helped, a lot, but it did not replace writing.

And so, all of that to just say, I'm very thankful to be able to type away again. To meander in my brain and pluck what I find and place it down on digital paper.

To ramble again, if no longer to rumble.

Rumbling is a young man's game.

Writing can be an old man's.

Something to look forward to (no old man here).

This might come across as sort of a down thing, but it's not.Â 

It's the exact opposite.

An up thing.

I'm writing again.

Wrote everyday here since early October.

I'm back, baby!

Or, at least, I am here.

I still get things off my chest, just now in a different form.

Lightweight, easy, easy.

What an interesting timeline.

To the last day of a good year.

Happy.

entry.title: Seconds To Last
entry.summary: I have always liked that word, "penultimate." Last but one. Second…
entry.content:
I have always liked that word, "penultimate."

Last but one.

Second to last.

The one right before the one before.

Pen...ultimate!

What a cool way to say almost last.

So here we are writing about penultimates.

How goes things?

You good?

You might think my asking about you is just a delay tactic.

A way to avoid writing anything of substance.

And to that I say, "How dare you!?"

You're right of course, but feigned outrage is my way to counter most things.

I got nothing to say, man. I'm still here.

I still believe in magic.

I know how the trick is done.

I know it by heart.

But I still believe in magic.

Watch this day vanish.

Poof!

How'd he do that?

And then the next one!

Poof!

Woah!

The whole year gone!

The trick is making the seconds last, even on the second to last.

POOF!

[The author vanishes in a puff of smoke, caused by a smoke machine which incidentally pumps out dance music from the 90s. Resulting in a dramatic, but not in the way he envisioned, end scene.]

â™« Is this some Reebok or some Nike? â™«

entry.title: Slingshots Slingshots Slingshots
entry.summary: One of the reasons I like to try new things is…
entry.content:
One of the reasons I like to try new things is because after a while, things can start sounding like an echo chamber.

You hear the same things over and over.

The same stuff said in a different way.

Groups agreeing with one another on everything and everyone.

And any ideas to the contrary are disregarded at best.

For me, I could agree with you vehemently on something, but if you keep pounding the idea home, I start to see the contrary views.Â 

Your certainty makes me doubt.

So I stay away from fanatics.Â 

On all sides.

Or, perhaps better said, keep them at a distance.

Some of my favorite ideas are led by people who basically say:

If you don't get it, you're just a moron.

Which, you should know by now, I understand.

Maybe it's the smugness.

Maybe that's why my brain goes, "Well, maybe there is another view here."

I always liked a well-written dissent over the more popular majority opinion.

"How are you liking the company?"

"Well, this company feels like a Goliath. And I have always been a David guy."

And maybe that's it.

Maybe if a room feels like it's full of drooling, nodding, giants, I instinctively grab my rounds.

Has the art of cordial disagreement faded away?

Agree to disagree?

Do professors still give out their best grades to students who disagree with their point of view, but do so so articulately and well-reasoned that it deserves a top grade?

My concern is it seems the world is flocking more and more into these silos of safety.

Where everyone in this silo has to think a certain way.

They all say the same things, believe the same things, and if you do not, well then, please see yourself out.

I am proud to say I have very few people I would call true friends. And believe it or not, some of them disagree with me. I know, I know, impossible, you say.

But it's true. They have their own ideas. Their own guidelines. And when I need to hear another side to an angle I am considering, I go there first.

Break this argument.

Shatter it.

What am I missing?

Don't echo.

Counter.

Left jab?

Right straight.

Left headkick?

Right legkick.

Get out of them chambers that have endless mirrors.

Who wants a million versions of themselves looking back at them?

Woah, cool.

entry.title: Fetch
entry.summary: One of the things I have always tried to distill is…
entry.content:
One of the things I have always tried to distill is this idea of success.

What is it?

How do you measure it?

How will you know when you are "successful?"

I mean, does a bell chime or does some little guy dressed as an elf dance at your side when it happens?

I think too many of us measure success by net worth.

And I suppose that's one way to do it.

I grew up with a terrible sense of money.

Didn't have much, didn't need much.

Maybe that's not so terrible.

But what I'm getting at is can you be a great family man and succeed in business?

Who's done that?

And who gets to measure whether you are successful or not?

You, your portfolio, or your family?

And what about your soul, your fortitude, your honor?Â 

Does that matter in the "success" formula?

I mean, ain't that the most important stick?

What I'm getting at is:

Did you have a good year?

And no matter your answer, how are you defining it?

entry.title: Everyday We Shuffling
entry.summary: Again, I sit down to write without an idea about what…
entry.content:
Again, I sit down to write without an idea about what to say.

I mean, I got a lot of ideas, but I am holding back on most things.

Some things do not belong on a blog.

But here I am.

So let's get to writing.

First of all, the word "blog" is terrible.

It stinks.

It's like the word, "brand."Â 

Yuck.

But yeah, I do both.

I suppose.

In my own anti-way.

Do it by not doing it right.

Or [waves hands] doing it different.

I'm yelling at people who cut in lines again.

I suppose that's something.

"Line starts back here, boys!"

That is kind of funny to me.

And then no-selling the "Oh, sorry" response.

Like I've moved on entirely.

Which I have.

Who is apologizing to me? And for what?

Next!

entry.title: Get To
entry.summary: I sit alone in a four cornered room staring at candles.
entry.content:
I sit alone in a four cornered room staring at candles.

Oh, is this thing on?

Listen, I hope you had yourself a Merry little Christmas.

And now, you find yourself getting ready to celebrate the end of the old year and to welcome the new.

I should wax on and wax off about ends and beginnings.

But that seems a little too cliche.

Why on earth would I do that?

Everyone does that.

And if you know a little something about me, I don't do what everyone does.

So here's what I will say.

Most of them out there are going to be lazy these last few days.

So there's opportunity in being especially active now.

While the others are celebrating, it is a great time to put in the work.

Sure, it's only a couple of days, but maybe you strike gold, while everyone else is drinking it.

Just remember, they can buy anything. But they can't buy backbone. Don't let them forget that.

And I know, I know, this is for like one person out of the millions (thousands, hundreds, dozens, handful) who read this nonsense.

But yes, this is for you, friend.

My words have never been for the crowd.

Just for the ones who can keep their heads.

I see you, back row, left side. On your feet. Clapping. Hollering. Underlining.

This is for you.

entry.title: Ho Ho Hoes
entry.summary: Merry Christmas. That was going to be it. But let's keep…
entry.content:
Merry Christmas.

That was going to be it.

But let's keep it going.

To those hurting in these times, I want to send a special message.

And to those in a great place, I also want to share the same message.

This, too, shall pass.

To those low, just survive.

And to those high, just bless.

Or maybe it's the reverse.

I forget.
